steps.title: Admissible t from the constraint
steps.content: For X ~ N(1, t^2), P(X ≤ 5t) = Φ((5t − 1)/t) = Φ(5 − 1/t). Since Φ(z) ≥ 1/2 iff z ≥ 0, the condition becomes 5 − 1/t ≥ 0, so t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Probability over the quadratic interval
steps.content: Standardizing with Z = (X − 1)/t ~ N(0, 1), the target probability is Φ(t + 1) − Φ(t − 1). Define g(t) = Φ(t + 1) − Φ(t − 1) for t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Maximize g(t) and evaluate
steps.content: g′(t) = φ(t + 1) − φ(t − 1), where φ is the standard normal pdf. For t ≥ 1/5 ≤ 1, φ(t + 1) < φ(1 − t) = φ(t − 1); for t ≥ 1, φ(t + 1) < φ(t − 1). Hence g′(t) < 0 on [1/5, ∞), so the maximum occurs at t = 1/5. Using the table, Φ(1.2) = 0.5 + 0.385 = 0.885 and Φ(−0.8) = 0.5 − 0.288 = 0.212, giving k = 0.885 − 0.212 = 0.673. Thus 1000k = 673.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: Relied on Attempt 1’s reasoning, confirming the monotonicity of g(t); no corrections were needed.

steps.title: Analyze the constraint P(X ≤ 5t) ≥ 1/2
steps.content: X follows N(1, t²), so X has mean μ = 1 and standard deviation σ = t. Standardizing: P(X ≤ 5t) = P(Z ≤ (5t-1)/t) ≥ 1/2. For P(Z ≤ z) ≥ 1/2, we need z ≥ 0. So (5t-1)/t ≥ 0, which means 5t - 1 ≥ 0 (since t > 0), giving t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Set up P(t²-t+1 ≤ X ≤ t²+t+1)
steps.content:
Standardizing with μ = 1 and σ = t:
Lower bound: (t²-t+1-1)/t = (t²-t)/t = t-1
Upper bound: (t²+t+1-1)/t = (t²+t)/t = t+1
So P(t²-t+1 ≤ X ≤ t²+t+1) = P(t-1 ≤ Z ≤ t+1)

steps.title: Express probability for different t ranges
Analyze behavior for 1/5 ≤ t < 1
steps.content:
Let g(t) = P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 1-t) + P(0 ≤ Z ≤ t+1)
g'(t) = -φ(1-t) + φ(t+1) where φ is the standard normal PDF.
φ(1-t) = φ(t+1) when 1-t = t+1 (gives t=0) or when |1-t| = |t+1|.
Since t > 0, we have 1-t < t+1 always.
For 0 < t < 1: 1-t > 0, so φ(1-t) > φ(t+1) because 1-t < t+1 and φ is decreasing for positive values.
Thus g'(t) = φ(t+1) - φ(1-t) < 0, so g(t) is decreasing on (1/5, 1).
Maximum for 1/5 ≤ t < 1 occurs at t = 1/5.

steps.title: Check at t = 1 and beyond
steps.content:
At t = 1: P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 2) - P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 0) = P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 2) ≈ 0.477
For t > 1: P(0 ≤ Z ≤ t+1) - P(0 ≤ Z ≤ t-1)
As t increases, this difference decreases (both approach 0.5).
At t = 1.2: P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 2.2) - P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 0.2) ≈ 0.486 - 0.079 ≈ 0.407
So for t ≥ 1, the probability is less than at t = 1/5.

steps.title: Determine maximum and final answer
steps.content:
Comparing values:
- At t = 1/5: probability = 0.673
- At t = 1: probability ≈ 0.477
- For t > 1: probability decreases further

The maximum occurs at t = 1/5, giving k = 0.673.
1000 × k = 1000 × 0.673 = 673

Claude Opus 4.5.feedback: Attempts 1 and 3 both correctly identified that the maximum occurs at t = 1/5 with probability 0.673. Attempt 2 made an error by confusing P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 2) with P(-1 ≤ Z ≤ 1) and incorrectly claimed the maximum was at t = 1. The key insight is that for 1/5 ≤ t < 1, the function g(t) = P(0 ≤ Z ≤ 1-t) + P(0 ≤ Z ≤ t+1) is decreasing because φ(1-t) > φ(t+1) (the normal PDF is higher at the smaller argument), making the derivative negative. Thus the maximum in this range is at the left boundary t = 1/5.

steps.title: Standardize and find feasible t
steps.content: Let Z=(X−1)/t~N(0,1). The condition P(X≤5t)≥1/2 becomes P(Z≤(5t−1)/t)≥1/2. Since Φ is increasing and Φ(0)=1/2, this is equivalent to (5t−1)/t≥0. With t>0, we get t≥1/5.

steps.title: Maximize over t
steps.content: f′(t)=φ(t+1)−φ(t−1). For t>0, |t+1|≥|t−1| and the standard normal pdf φ decreases with |x|, so φ(t+1)≤φ(t−1) with strict inequality for t>0. Hence f is strictly decreasing on (0,∞), so the maximum on t≥1/5 occurs at t=1/5.

steps.title: Evaluate at t=1/5 using the table

GPT-5.feedback: All three attempts use the same correct approach: standardize, deduce t≥1/5 from the median property of the normal, show f(t)=Φ(t+1)−Φ(t−1) is decreasing via φ(t+1)<φ(t−1), and evaluate at t=1/5 using the provided table. No corrections were needed; I relied on the shared reasoning across the attempts.

steps.title: Identify the condition for t
steps.content: X ~ N(1, t²), so P(X ≤ 5t) = Φ(5 - 1/t) ≥ 1/2. Since Φ(0) = 0.5, this holds for 5 - 1/t ≥ 0, i.e., t ≥ 1/5 = 0.2.

steps.title: Express the probability
steps.content: P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1), where Z ~ N(0,1).

steps.title: Find the maximum
steps.content: The function Φ(t+1) - Φ(t-1) is decreasing for t > 0 because its derivative φ(t+1) - φ(t-1) < 0. Thus, the maximum occurs at t = 0.2.

Grok 4 Fast.feedback: None of the previous attempts correctly interpreted the problem. Attempt 1 misread as Poisson/Gamma. Attempt 2 used wrong parameters. Attempt 3 used incorrect interval width and z=1.4. Developed a new correct approach using standardization and table values for z=0.8 and 1.2.

steps.title: Find the constraint on t from P(X ≤ 5t) ≥ 1/2
steps.content:
Given X ~ N(1, t²) where t > 0. To find P(X ≤ 5t), I standardize: Z = (X - 1)/t ~ N(0, 1).

P(X ≤ 5t) = P(Z ≤ (5t - 1)/t) = P(Z ≤ 5 - 1/t) = Φ(5 - 1/t)

For this to be ≥ 1/2, since Φ(0) = 0.5 and Φ is increasing, we need:
5 - 1/t ≥ 0
1/t ≤ 5
t ≥ 1/5 = 0.2

So the constraint is t ≥ 0.2.

steps.title: Express the target probability in terms of standard normal
steps.content:
I need to find P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1).

Standardizing the bounds:
Lower: (t² - t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² - t)/t = t - 1
Upper: (t² + t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² + t)/t = t + 1

So P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1)

steps.title: Analyze when this probability is maximized
steps.content:
Let f(t) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1) for t ≥ 0.2.

Taking the derivative:
f'(t) = φ(t + 1) - φ(t - 1)

where φ(x) = (1/√(2π))e^(-x²/2) is the standard normal PDF.

For t > 0: t + 1 > 0 always. Also |t + 1| > |t - 1| for t > 0.
Since φ(x) = φ(-x) and φ is decreasing for x > 0, we have φ(t + 1) < φ(|t - 1|) = φ(t - 1).

Therefore f'(t) = φ(t + 1) - φ(t - 1) < 0 for all t > 0.

This means f(t) is strictly decreasing on (0, ∞), so the maximum on t ≥ 0.2 occurs at t = 0.2.

steps.title: Compute the final answer
steps.content:
The maximum value k = 0.673.

Therefore, 1000 × k = 1000 × 0.673 = 673.

self_aggregation.rationale: All four model solutions agree on the answer 673 and follow the same logical approach: (1) finding t ≥ 1/5 from the constraint, (2) standardizing the target probability to Φ(t+1) - Φ(t-1), (3) showing this is decreasing in t, so maximum is at t = 1/5, and (4) calculating using the table. The reasoning is mathematically sound.

steps.title: Determine feasible t-range
steps.content: Standardize P(X ≤ 5t) for X ~ N(1, t²): P(Z ≤ (5t-1)/t) ≥ 1/2 ⇔ (5t-1)/t ≥ 0 ⇒ t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Express target probability
steps.content: With Z = (X-1)/t ∼ N(0,1), we have P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1) = Φ(t+1) − Φ(t−1).

steps.title: Maximize over admissible t
steps.content: Differentiate g(t)=Φ(t+1)−Φ(t−1): g′(t)=φ(t+1)−φ(t−1) < 0 for all t ≥ 1/5, so maximum at t = 1/5. Using the table: Φ(1.2)=0.885, Φ(−0.8)=0.212, hence k = 0.673 and 1000k = 673.

GPT-5-Codex.feedback: My reasoning matches Claude Opus and GPT-5; all locate the maximum at t = 1/5 and compute 1000k = 673. Grok’s solution tackles a different distribution and is incorrect. No changes were necessary.

steps.title: Analyze the distribution and first condition
steps.content: X follows N(1, t²), meaning μ = 1 and σ = t. For P(X ≤ 5t) ≥ 1/2, we standardize: P(Z ≤ (5t-1)/t) ≥ 1/2. Since P(Z ≤ 0) = 1/2 and Φ is increasing, we need (5t-1)/t ≥ 0, which means 5 - 1/t ≥ 0, so t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Set up the probability for the second condition
steps.content:
We need to find P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1). Standardizing with μ = 1 and σ = t:
Lower bound: (t² - t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² - t)/t = t - 1
Upper bound: (t² + t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² + t)/t = t + 1
So P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1) = Φ(t+1) - Φ(t-1)

steps.title: Analyze the function to maximize
steps.content: Define g(t) = Φ(t+1) - Φ(t-1) for t ≥ 1/5. Taking derivative: g'(t) = φ(t+1) - φ(t-1), where φ is the standard normal density. For 1/5 ≤ t < 1: t-1 is negative, so φ(t-1) = φ(1-t). Since 1-t < t+1 for t > 0, and φ decreases away from 0, we have φ(1-t) > φ(t+1), so g'(t) < 0. For t ≥ 1: both t-1 and t+1 are positive, with t-1 < t+1, so φ(t-1) > φ(t+1), meaning g'(t) < 0. Thus g(t) is strictly decreasing for all t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Find maximum at boundary
steps.content: Since g(t) is strictly decreasing for t ≥ 1/5, the maximum occurs at the smallest allowed value t = 1/5.

The calculation is confirmed correct.

steps.title: Maximize over feasible t
steps.content: f(t)=Φ(t+1)−Φ(t−1), f′(t)=φ(t+1)−φ(t−1). For all t>0, φ(t+1)<φ(t−1) ⇒ f′(t)<0. Thus f decreases on (0,∞) and is maximized at the smallest feasible t, t=1/5.

steps.title: Determine feasible t from the constraint
steps.content: X ~ N(1, t²), so Z = (X - 1)/t ~ N(0,1). The constraint P(X ≤ 5t) ≥ 1/2 is Φ((5t - 1)/t) = Φ(5 - 1/t) ≥ 1/2. Since Φ is increasing and Φ(0) = 1/2, this holds iff 5 - 1/t ≥ 0 ⇒ t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Express the target probability
steps.content: P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1). Define g(t) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1) for t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Maximize g(t)
steps.content: g'(t) = φ(t + 1) - φ(t - 1). For t ≥ 1/5, |t - 1| < |t + 1|, so φ(t - 1) > φ(t + 1) due to the symmetry and decreasing nature of φ for positive arguments. Thus g'(t) < 0, so g(t) is decreasing and maximized at t = 1/5.

steps.title: Understand the distribution and constraint
steps.content: X follows a normal distribution N(1, t²), where the mean μ = 1 and variance σ² = t², so σ = t (since t > 0). We standardize using Z = (X - 1)/t ~ N(0,1).

steps.title: Analyze the constraint P(X ≤ 5t) ≥ 1/2
steps.content:
P(X ≤ 5t) = P((X-1)/t ≤ (5t-1)/t) = P(Z ≤ 5 - 1/t) = Φ(5 - 1/t).

For this probability to be at least 1/2, we need Φ(5 - 1/t) ≥ 1/2.

Since Φ(0) = 1/2 and Φ is strictly increasing, we need:
5 - 1/t ≥ 0
5 ≥ 1/t
t ≥ 1/5

So the feasible region is t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Express the target probability
steps.content:
We want P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1).

Standardizing the bounds:
Lower: (t² - t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² - t)/t = t - 1
Upper: (t² + t + 1 - 1)/t = (t² + t)/t = t + 1

So P(t² - t + 1 ≤ X ≤ t² + t + 1) = P(t - 1 ≤ Z ≤ t + 1) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1).

steps.title: Analyze the function to maximize
steps.content:
Let g(t) = Φ(t + 1) - Φ(t - 1) for t ≥ 1/5.

Taking the derivative: g'(t) = φ(t + 1) - φ(t - 1), where φ is the standard normal PDF.

Since φ(z) = (1/√(2π))e^(-z²/2), and φ is symmetric about 0 and decreasing for |z| increasing:

For t ≥ 1/5: We compare |t + 1| and |t - 1|.
- When 0 < t < 1: t + 1 > 0 and t - 1 < 0, so |t + 1| = t + 1 and |t - 1| = 1 - t. Since t + 1 > 1 - t for t > 0, we have |t + 1| > |t - 1|, so φ(t + 1) < φ(t - 1).
- When t ≥ 1: Both t + 1 > t - 1 ≥ 0, so φ(t + 1) < φ(t - 1).

In both cases, g'(t) = φ(t + 1) - φ(t - 1) < 0.

Thus g(t) is strictly decreasing for all t ≥ 1/5.

steps.title: Find the maximum
steps.content: Since g(t) is strictly decreasing for t ≥ 1/5, the maximum occurs at the smallest feasible value: t = 1/5.

cross_aggregation.rationale: All four model solutions agree on the approach and final answer. The constraint analysis correctly yields t ≥ 1/5, the standardization gives P(t-1 ≤ Z ≤ t+1), the function is proven decreasing so maximum is at t = 1/5, and the calculation using the table gives k = 0.673.
